subdoc-abstract.paragraph: A distinct cultivar of Rubus plant named ‘Golden Quilt’, characterized by its compact, prostrate and cascading plant habit; freely basal branching habit; yellow green-colored young foliage that turns green with development; and burgundy-colored foliage during the fall.

section.heading: BACKGROUND OF THE INVENTION
section.paragraph: [0001] The present invention relates to a new and distinct cultivar of Rubus plant, botanically known as Rubus calycinoides and hereinafter referred to by the name ‘Golden Quilt’.

[0002] The new Rubus is a naturally-occurring branch mutation of an unidentified selection of Rubus calycinoides, not patented. The new Rubus was discovered by the Inventor in a controlled environment in Atlanta, Ga. in May, 1998.

[0003] Asexual reproduction ofthe new Rubus by vegetative stem cuttings taken in a controlled environment in Dahlonega, Ga. since June, 1998, has shown that the unique features of this new Rubus are stable and reproduced true to type in successive generations.

section.heading: SUMMARY OF THE INVENTION
section.paragraph: [0004] The cultivar Golden Quilt has not been observed under all possible environmental conditions. The phenotype may vary somewhat with variations in environment such as temperature, daylength, light intensity, and water and nutritional status without, however, any variance in genotype.

[0005] The following traits have been repeatedly observed and are determined to be the unique characteristics of ‘Golden Quilt’. These characteristics in combination distinguish ‘Golden Quilt’ as a new and distinct cultivar:
[0006] 1. Compact, prostrate and cascading plant habit.
[0008] 3. Yellow green-colored young foliage that turns green with development.

[0010] Plants of the new Rubus can be compared to plants of the parent, the unidentified Rubus selection. In side-by-side comparisons conducted in Atlanta, Ga., plants of the new Rubus and the unidentified Rubus selection differ in the following characteristics:
[0011] 1. Plants of the new Rubus are slightly slower growing than plants of the unidentified Rubus selection.
[0012] 2. Young leaves of plants of the new Rubus are yellow green in color whereas young leaves of plants of the unidentified Rubus selection are solid green in color.

section.heading: BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF THE PHOTOGRAPH
section.paragraph: [0013] The accompanying colored photograph illustrates the overall appearance of the new Rubus, showing the colors as true as it is reasonably possible to obtain in colored reproductions of this type. Colors in the photograph may differ slightly from the color values cited in the detailed botanical description which accurately describe the colors of the new Rubus. The photograph comprises a top perspective view of a six month-old plant of ‘Golden Quilt’.

section.heading: DETAILED BOTANICAL DESCRIPTION
section.paragraph: [0014] In the following description, color references are made to The Royal Horticultural Society Colour Chart except where general terms of ordinary dictionary significance are used. The following observations and measurements describe plants grown in Atlanta, Ga., under conditions which approximate commercial practice in an unshaded outdoor nursery. During the production of the plants, day temperatures ranged from 50 to 95° F. and night temperatures ranged from 30 to 80° F. Measurements and numerical values represent averages of six month-old plants grown in 15-cm containers. Measurements and color values were taken on plants during the spring and early summer.

section.heading: PARENTAGE
section.paragraph: [0016] Naturally-occurring branch mutation of an unidentified selection of Rubus calycinoides, not patented

section.heading: PROPAGATION
section.paragraph: [0021] Time to produce a rooted cutting:
[0024] Root description: Fine, freely branching, and white in color.

section.heading: PLANT DESCRIPTION
section.paragraph: [0026] Growth habit: Freely basal branching; about 10 to 12 basal shoots per plant.
[0034] Texture.—Fine white pubescence; occasional random thorns on younger stems. Thorns about 1 mm in length, about 1 mm in height, and close to 183A to 187A in color.
[0035] Color.—Young stems: 144A to 144B. Mature stems: Close to 175A.
[0037] Arrangement.—Leaves simple; symmetrical; alternate. Length: From petiole attachment to apex: About 3.1 cm From basal lobes to apex: About 4 cm.
[0039] Shape.—Roughly cordate with five rounded lobes.

highlight.italic: Texture.—Upper surface: Waxy, smooth, sparsely pubescent Lower surface: Densely pubescent.

section.paragraph: [0045] Color.—Young foliage, upper surface: Initially mostly yellow green, between 7A and 154A; then venal areas, between 7A and 154A and interveinal areas, closest to 141A. Young foliage, lower surface: Closest to 147C to 147D. Mature foliage, upper surface: More green than 147A. Mature foliage, lower surface: Closest to 147C to 147D. Fall coloration, upper surface: Close to 185A. Fall coloration, lower surface: Closest to 147C to 147D. Venation, upper surface: Closest to 141A to 147A. Venation, lower surface: Closest to 145A.
[0052] Quantity/arrangement.—Two at base of each petiole.

highlight.italic: Texture.—Upper surface: Smooth, glabrous. Lower surface: Pubescent.

section.paragraph: [0057] Color.—Upper surface: Closeto 143A. Lower surface: Close to 144A.

section.heading: FLOWER DESCRIPTION
section.paragraph: [0058] Flower development has not been observed on plants of the new Rubus.

section.heading: DISEASE RESISTANCE:
section.paragraph: [0059] Plants of the new Rubus have not been observed to be resistant to pathogens common to Rubus.

claim.claim-text: 1. A new and distinct cultivar of Rubus plant named ‘Golden Quilt’, as illustrated and described.
